description: This PR creates a new frontend for GAMER, which is a GPU-accelerated patch-based AMR code soon to be released. It includes the answer tests for two datasets, interacting jets and wave dark matter halo. Documentation will be added once the code is released.
title: GAMER frontend

content.raw:
A couple comments:

The test datasets still need to have references on yt-project.org/data. Let me know if you have questions about updating the website.

You need to update the documentation to reflect support for GAMER. These pages in particular:

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/examining/index.html

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/reference/code_support.html

Let me know if you have questions about updating the documentation.

content.raw: This dataset in the HDF5 file is guaranteed to exist if it's a valid GAMER file?
content.html: This dataset in the HDF5 file is guaranteed to exist if it's a valid GAMER file?

content.raw:
Just as a general comment, you should try to avoid creating class attributes and local variable names that are all-caps or in camel-case, instead preferring lowercase_underscore names. In Python only class names are in camel case.

Some of the code in this pull request would also be much more readable if it used more descriptive variable names. For example `Para` could be `parameters`, `PID` could be `patch_id`, `CrList` could be `grid_corners`.

It looks like some of this terminology is inherited from GAMER, and it makes sense to use names from GAMER where that makes sense, but at least local variable names can use more descriptive names for the benefit of future readers of this frontend.
content.html:
Just as a general comment, you should try to avoid creating class attributes and local variable names that are all-caps or in camel-case, instead preferring lowercase_underscore names. In Python only class names are in camel case.

Some of the code in this pull request would also be much more readable if it used more descriptive variable names. For example Para could be parameters, PID could be patch_id, CrList could be grid_corners.

It looks like some of this terminology is inherited from GAMER, and it makes sense to use names from GAMER where that makes sense, but at least local variable names can use more descriptive names for the benefit of future readers of this frontend.

content.raw:
I think this could be generally useful if you put it in the `GridIndex` class, although we don't really have a concept of a debug mode elsewhere.

It looks like some of the implementation of `_validate_parent_children_relasionship` is GAMER-specific, but a lot of it could be reused by other frontends. I can show you how to do this cleanly using python's `super` function so that some of the implementation is in the base class, but then there's some specialized bits in this class (sorry if you already know about that - trying to avoid being condescending).
content.html:
I think this could be generally useful if you put it in the GridIndex class, although we don't really have a concept of a debug mode elsewhere.

It looks like some of the implementation of _validate_parent_children_relasionship is GAMER-specific, but a lot of it could be reused by other frontends. I can show you how to do this cleanly using python's super function so that some of the implementation is in the base class, but then there's some specialized bits in this class (sorry if you already know about that - trying to avoid being condescending).

content.raw: Can you delete this line? We try to avoid having commented code in the codebase.
content.html: Can you delete this line? We try to avoid having commented code in the codebase.

content.raw: Is the unit metadata not in the output file?
content.html: Is the unit metadata not in the output file?

content.raw:
I guess we get to invent yt-native field names for this here? What about `real_part_dark_matter_density`? Maybe that's too wordy.

My worry with just `real_part` is what happens when we deal with other imaginary fields elsewhere in yt?
content.html:
I guess we get to invent yt-native field names for this here? What about real_part_dark_matter_density? Maybe that's too wordy.

My worry with just real_part is what happens when we deal with other imaginary fields elsewhere in yt?

content.raw: Yes. This is the first grid on the root level.
content.html: Yes. This is the first grid on the root level.

content.raw: I don't *think* it matters, but it looks like the other frontends use yt names for fields, not native names when they define frontend-specific fields. I'd just double check that these fields are coming out in the correct units.
content.html: I don't think it matters, but it looks like the other frontends use yt names for fields, not native names when they define frontend-specific fields. I'd just double check that these fields are coming out in the correct units.

content.raw: Maybe it's safer to check if `['Level_00']['Cluster_%09i'%0]['Patch_%09i'%0]` exists? Since you use that later and it's a bit more specific.
content.html: Maybe it's safer to check if ['Level_00']['Cluster_%09i'%0]['Patch_%09i'%0] exists? Since you use that later and it's a bit more specific.

content.raw: Looks great! I have a few minor comments, but I'm very happy with this. I'm glad that the bulk of the code ends up being relatively simple.
content.html: Looks great! I have a few minor comments, but I'm very happy with this. I'm glad that the bulk of the code ends up being relatively simple.

content.raw: Thanks for the suggestions, and I agree with you. I haven't thought that users who just use but not develop GAMER may be unfamiliar with the terminology adopted in the code. I will revise it in the next commit.
content.html: Thanks for the suggestions, and I agree with you. I haven't thought that users who just use but not develop GAMER may be unfamiliar with the terminology adopted in the code. I will revise it in the next commit.

content.raw: I'm noticing there's some commented code elsewhere in this PR, I'd delete that too.
content.html: I'm noticing there's some commented code elsewhere in this PR, I'd delete that too.

content.raw: OK I'll do that.
content.html: OK I'll do that.

content.raw: Agree.
content.html: Agree.

content.raw: It seems that different energies have different units in YT (or in Enzo). For example, kinematic energy is per **volume**, but total energy and thermal energy are per **mass**. I think that's really confusing and that's the main reason I use native name **Engy** here.
content.html: It seems that different energies have different units in YT (or in Enzo). For example, kinematic energy is per volume, but total energy and thermal energy are per mass. I think that's really confusing and that's the main reason I use native name Engy here.

content.raw: Good point. How about `psidm_real_part`, where psidm stands for wave dark matter.
content.html: Good point. How about psidm_real_part, where psidm stands for wave dark matter.

content.raw: Unfortunately I haven't implemented a good unit system in GAMER. So now it relies on `units_override`, similar to `Athena`.
content.html: Unfortunately I haven't implemented a good unit system in GAMER. So now it relies on units_override, similar to Athena.

content.raw: Just to remind myself of adding `thermal energy`, which is **specific energy**.
content.html: Just to remind myself of adding thermal energy, which is specific energy.

content.raw: I think this will be a *lot* slower than if you were to cache access to the sub-sets.  (It will only show up when accessing multiple fields at the same time.)  So if in the outer loop you cached `self._handle[LvName][CName][PName]` and then inside the loop only did `[field[1]]`.
content.html: I think this will be a lot slower than if you were to cache access to the sub-sets. (It will only show up when accessing multiple fields at the same time.) So if in the outer loop you cached self._handle[LvName][CName][PName] and then inside the loop only did [field[1]].

content.raw:
Modifications include:

1. Rewrite HDF5 data format following FLASH. The I/O bandwidth has been verified to be similar to that of FLASH.
2. Rename internal variables to be lower-case and more readable
3. Add the *internal_energy* and *total_energy* fields
4. Update the document about how to specify units for the GAMER frontend
5. Datasets with the new data format for the answer test have been uploaded to the yt website
content.html:
Modifications include:

  1. Rewrite HDF5 data format following FLASH. The I/O bandwidth has been verified to be similar to that of FLASH.
  2. Rename internal variables to be lower-case and more readable
  3. Add the internal_energy and total_energy fields
  4. Update the document about how to specify units for the GAMER frontend
  5. Datasets with the new data format for the answer test have been uploaded to the yt website
